ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This class taught me loads of new signs and radically improved my ASL proficiency. I love signing, so that was very fulfilling, but I was most excited to learn so much more about Deaf culture and critical Deaf studies. This course made me hyped to learn more in ASL 3!
This skill helped me build my vocabulary in ASL, while also learning more about Deaf Culture.
I think my major skills in the realm of ability to sign as well as ability to understand sign really improved, as well as my understanding of Deaf culture across different communities.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: The ASL program is such a welcoming, fun environment, and I was excited to come to class every day. That was certainly helped by the 4-day-a-week structure of the class, which compassionately lets students take Fridays off in exchange for writing in a journal and working on a fun service project. This semester there were lots of games incorporated into class, which was a huge improvement on last semester! 

Weakness: None, except that I know a number of folks struggled with their main service project. I love the idea of having service projects, but communicating/coordinating with large groups of busy Yale students to plan things can be very difficult. I don't want to suggest putting any extra burden of organizing service projects on the professors; maybe we could have a more formal option to do an independent research project/presentation instead?
This class is truly one of thr best at Yale as are all thr ASL courses. The professors are fantastic, the structure makes it easy to learn, and it's very easy to be engaged.
I think the course itself is really great the one thing I would potentially reevaluate is the project as a part of the final project.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely  learning ASL has given me the opportunity to communicate with more people, expand my understanding of Deaf Culture, and create more inclusive student environments on campus. As a graduating senior, this is the best choice I've made in my entire academic career.
Yes! ASL is a fantastic way to fulfill the language requirement!

I would absolutely recommend that all of my friends take ASL! It is useful, inclusive, fun, and totally worthwhile. I would also recommend taking it with Andrew; he is one of the most compassionate and understanding professors I have ever met, and he makes learning ASL so much fun!
Yes! The class is great. It's not incredibly difficult, but you learn a lot.
Absolutely, it was a fantastic engaging course that I would recommend to everyone!
